Expectation1: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation1: A client has an inquiry about a specific line item on their most recent invoice.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: The city newsletter includes a short survey about bus routes open through next week.
Story: I was in the middle of reviewing invoices when my phone buzzed with an email from a client. They were confused about a line item on their most recent bill and wanted clarification as soon as possible. As their accountant, I knew I needed to respond quickly and clearly—good communication keeps trust strong and payments timely. I started drafting my reply, but then I noticed the city newsletter in my inbox. The city was asking for feedback on proposed changes to the bus routes, and the survey would close next week. As a citizen, I felt a responsibility to participate; I rely on those buses, and I know others do too. I wanted to give thoughtful feedback, but I also knew my client was waiting. My mind raced between the urgency of my professional duty and the importance of my civic voice. I stared at both emails, feeling the pressure of two worlds pulling me in different directions, unsure which to answer first.
